ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class prompts you to think about your personal history/ archive in a way that's novel and refreshing. Though this does make your learning rather internal, communal sharing/ reflection helps build a community.

Developed skills and language to read and analyze non-fiction films of varying content, but mostly focused on themes of family, culture, and identity. We were able to pair films with readings that gave insights into filmic and photographic histories and strategies that aided our discussions in class.
I developed my capacity to think critically about the various ways that family and communal stories are told, and consider how I want to intervene in those narratives.

I learned how to look at films in a more holistic manner, was exposed to some great films I was sadly unaware of, gained a more in depth insight on how we, as humans, develop our personal narratives, and, most importantly, I learned the value of lived experience over academic jargon

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Professor Harris is a great teacher who cares for and is genuinely interested in his students. The films we watched were deeply moving and the seminar environment was great.

I wish we'd had more in-class time to workshop and get guidance on our research.

Given that this is an unprecedented situation, and that learning like that can be challenging, the course was wonderfully tailored for this odd semester. The only weakness I could find was the fact that we had to rent some of the movies ourselves. I would expect from an institution such as Yale to be able to provide full access to these media for its students, unless there was access and simply I was not aware of this.

Also, some of the movies included very sensitive content and adding trigger warnings on the syllabus would me immensely valuable and appreciated.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: At the beginning zoom fatigue was not taken into consideration so two hours in front of a screen, having complicated conversations was a little bit of a stretch. Luckily, the instructor was flexible and added breaks.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes!!! Thomas Allen Harris has a broad and deep understanding of film history and brings his own practice and experience as a filmmaker into the course. It's very generative for a student looking to begin studying non-fiction film techniques!
Yes! This is a stimulating and personally relevant class that you can take in any number of directions and have a fulfilling and transformative experience.
Absolutely. It is well structured, rich in the areas it covers, intriguing, and extremely interesting.
